Given that government undertakings in relation to a greenhouse trigger were part of the deal with the Democrats to get the government's environmental legislation through the Senate, will the minister deliver on those undertakings and his own public statements about a trigger, or will he bow to pressure from the Deputy Prime Minister, Senator Minchin and others and abandon this proposal?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I am glad Senator Quirke has time for questions. He has obviously now pulled the knife out of Senator Schacht's back and he can get back to real business.

—Senator Bolkus intervenes! Of course, it was the pincer move-ment between the left and the right, with poor Senator Schacht the victim. We on this side think that Senator Schacht was treated extremely poorly, Senator Quirke. Although Senator Quirke has returned to the table, I think he has somewhat misquoted what I said in the estimates committee. Let us check the Hansard because I do not recall saying that I believed it was essential. What I would have said is that it would have been a useful—
—What you should have said!

—What I would have said is in all likelihood what I did say. What I would have said is that it would be a useful tool for the federal government because of course the federal government is the level of government that has accepted obligations under the Kyoto protocol.
—Senator Faulkner! Senator Bolkus! I draw your attention to the standing orders.

—Under a greenhouse trigger major developments planned, very high emission developments—I am talking about very large developments, the equivalent of 10 per cent of total increased emissions in Australia within each year—would come to the Commonwealth government for analysis as to their greenhouse conse-quences. As a result of that, the Commonwealth government might well provide input to the developer, which could lead to modifications of the project and perhaps a better greenhouse outcome. That is what a Commonwealth greenhouse trigger would be all about.

answer.para: The government has commenced a process of consultation with the states pursuant to the COAG agreement entered into between the Commonwealth and the states that set out matters of national environmental significance ultimately included under the current EPBC Act. That process of consultation is taking place. A paper was written by a consultant and distributed to all interested parties. Many submissions were received on it. As a result of that, a preferred model was developed, which was then distributed to the states for further consultation. That is the stage the matter has reached. When consultations have been completed, I will take to cabinet a final preferred model which will best meet the wishes of government if it seeks to introduce a regulatory greenhouse trigger as a matter of national environmental significance. That is the process that is taking place. Nothing has changed thereunder. If Senator Quirke remains patient, he will find out the final outcome in due course.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Is it true that the Minister for the Environment and Heritage is eventually to be stripped of responsibility for greenhouse matters and that this responsibility will be taken over by Senator Minchin? Does the minister propose to implement his greenhouse trigger before Senator Minchin takes over? How is Mr Brindal's health, Minister?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —How is Mr Brindal's health?
—You in your office, knifing Brindal.

—Don't you talk about knives, Senator! Look at Senator Schacht. I could say that Australia's domestic response to the greenhouse challenge is as good as, if not better than, that of any country in the world. We are proud of what we have done since the end of 1997 to modify the Australian economy in different ways so that we can meet the target we agreed to at Kyoto—a fair target. We are pleased that we have a ministerial council which includes all relevant ministers, including Senator Minchin, and which is guiding the Australian Greenhouse Office towards the implementation of the best mix of policies to achieve the target that Australia committed to. That is what this debate is all about—Australia paying a fair price for moving towards a better global outcome. (Time expired)

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I am wondering if the minister can explain how the government's new amendments to the Gene Technology Bill 2000 will protect the environment from any adverse impacts of genetically modified organisms, given that there is no requirement for advice from the minister for the environment or incorporation of any advice on the release of GMOs if offered. Is the minister aware of the comments by the Executive Director of the National Farmers Federation, Dr Wendy Craik, that the Democrat proposal `emphasise(d) environmental issues above other issues'? Is this not an appropriate objective for the proposed office of gene technology and, of course, in keeping with the wishes of the Australian people? So, could the minister explain if this government backdown—and also now the Prime Minister's intervention in the food labelling issue—is indicative of the disregard that this government has not only for public concerns about GMOs but the public consultations conducted by the health department about this bill?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Stott Despoja for the question. To respond to the last one, no, the government has a very serious concern about public concern, but I can draw her attention to the fact that the minister is aware of media criticisms of the Interim Office of the Gene Technology Regulator in relation to its ability to investigate breaches and take remedial action. I am also aware that there has been some speculation that the ability of the environment minister to provide appropriate advice has been eroded. The minister has received a progress report on the investigation of breaches in the Mount Gambier region and expects that the final report will be provided to him in the near future. He is aware that the office has taken the time to be most thorough in its examination of the alleged breaches while remaining cognisant of the need to provide natural justice to the company concerned.

answer.para: Referring now to the legislation currently being developed by the Interim Office of the Gene Technology Regulator, the minister believes that will strengthen the current regulatory framework to prevent breaches like those just mentioned. It will also provide the environment minister with the ability to provide him and the Office of Gene Tech-nology Regulator with advice. That Gene Technology Bill 2000, which will be introduced into parliament shortly, will create a statutory office holder, to be known as the Gene Technology Regulator, who will have the power to enforce stringent safeguards for the research, development, production and use of genetically modified organisms for the health and environmental safety of Australians. The bill is the result of an extensive consultation process which commenced in October last year and involved all relevant Commonwealth portfolios, all state and territory governments and interested stakeholders as well as the general public. The object of the legislation is to protect the health and safety of people and to protect the environment from any risks posed by genetically modified organisms. The proposed legislation therefore places very strong emphasis on environmental issues. The Gene Technology Regulator will be required to seek and take account of the environment minister's advice in relation to all applications for the intentional release of a genetically modified organism into the environment. No other minister, state or Commonwealth, is afforded such a specific role, and this provides additional assurance that appropriate environmental assessments are made in relation to genetically modified organisms. Where risks to the environment and/or public health cannot be properly managed, releases will not be permitted.

The introduction of the bill into parlia-ment is consistent with the government's aim to have the Office of the Gene Technology Regulator fully operational by January 2001. The new legislation will also create a much stronger regulatory regime than exists under the current interim arrangements. It proposes that the regulator or person authorised by the regulator will be able to enter into any premises covered by a licence to deal with genetically modified organisms in order to monitor compliance with the legislation. And the regulator is not required to give prior notice or advance warning of spot checks. Inspectors under the bill will have entry and search powers akin to the Australian Federal Police. Penalties for criminal offences under the draft bill are significant: up to $1.1 million for each individual breach of the law and relevant parts of the criminal code has been included in the draft Gene Technology Bill 2000. The proposed regulatory system for genetically modified organisms is rigorous and stringent. I am not aware of the statement made by Wendy Craik, but I will refer that to the minister.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his response, but I do not understand how the minister can argue that there is an emphasis on environmental issues in this bill or claim that he wants to see strong protections for the environment when the role of the minister for the environment under the proposed amendments, the new amendments, has been completely undermined. The role of the environment minister has been completely undermined under the new proposed amendments as opposed to the Democrat amendments. I ask once again if this government has complete disregard for public and community concerns about GMOs, as well as the adverse impact of GMOs on the environment, as well as health and safety concerns?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Madam President, the answer is no.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Black Economy

talker.name: Cook, Sen Peter
Senator COOK
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the Assistant Treasurer aware of the following statement by Minister Reith on the SundaySunrise program yesterday:

quote.para: We are talking about a lot of black economy here. Treasury's estimates have been an extra $3.5 billion from the black economy.

question.para: Can the minister confirm that Treasury officials have on a number of occasions told Senate committees that no estimates of the black economy have been undertaken? Who is telling the truth on this issue of Treasury estimates—Minister Reith or the Treasury officials?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Mr Reith was expressing his own personal views.
—You'd be on his side, would you?

—Let me go through some of the issues which were raised at Senate estimates. I believe Senator Cook was there. There were discussions about the size of the cash economy. Not surprisingly, the estimates involved ranged considerably.
—If you weren't before, you would be now.
—Senator Bolkus, if you would like to listen for a change, you might actually learn something.
—Not from you, I wouldn't.
—Senator Bolkus, cease interjecting.

—Thank you, Madam President. The new tax system will make inroads on the cash economy. The estimate of the increased revenue from the cash economy under the new tax system is some $3.5 billion. There has been no change to this estimate.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, when you say that Mr Reith was talking for himself, are you talking about the part where he said that he estimates the black economy would be double that figure—namely, extra GST receipts of $7 billion? Can the Assistant Treasurer shed light on the embarrassing contradiction of Mr Reith's statement by the Treasurer's spokeswoman, who said that there was no additional revenue in the forecast? Or has the Treasurer's spokeswoman not yet been nicked for this blatant manoeuvre in the leadership stakes?
—The second part of the question is quite irrelevant. If there is anything in the first part of the supplementary question you wish to comment upon, Senator Kemp, please do so.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The questions get worse and worse during the day. That one was a classic Senator Cook non-question. The only people making complete fools of themselves at the moment are the Labor Party. The Labor Party are in total confusion on their tax policy. They go around attempting to promote scares, but as soon as the question is asked, `What do the Labor Party propose to do about it?' the answer is, `The Labor Party propose to keep the GST.' But the really dopey aspect of the Labor Party is that, because of the very big tax cuts coming through on 1 July, the Labor Party are asked to guarantee that their policy will confirm these tax cuts, and do they run for cover. We are going to deliver major tax cuts to the Australian public against the wishes of the Australian Labor Party.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Tax Re-form

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Would the min-ister inform the Senate how communities in rural and regional Australia will benefit from the new tax system? Is the minister aware of alternative policies? What would be the impact of these policies?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The effect of the new tax system on rural and regional Australia is a very important issue. I can assure you, Madam President, that the new tax system will deliver major benefits to our rural and regional communities. They will share in the $12 billion of personal income tax cuts, which will be delivered in full and on time in just 11 days. What a contrast to Labor's l-a- w law tax cuts, which disappeared after the 1993 election. The new tax system will also deliver major cuts in the cost of transport by reducing the cost of diesel in rural areas by 24c a litre. That will be a major benefit to our rural exporters, who rely on the transport industry to get their produce to Australian ports. The new tax system will ensure that all exports are GST free. In all, an estimated $3.5 billion tax burden will be lifted off the backs of Australian exporters. It is a simple equation. More exports mean more jobs, and that is good news for the Australian community. Even the Labor spokesman, Mr McMullan agrees. He said:

quote.para: Well, the GST overall should be good for exports.

talk.start.para: —Yes, I will repeat it, if you like. Mr McMullan said, with a touch of honesty, that overall the GST will be good for exports. Rural and regional economies will also benefit from the changes to the business tax system. I quote the President of the National Farmers Federation, who said:

quote.para: It's worth remembering that the all-up savings for the farm sector from the introduction of the indirect tax package including the GST, and consequent reductions in fuel excise, are estimated to be around $900 million—every year—and, of course, there will be flow-on benefits to the whole community.

answer.para: He was absolutely right. So the new tax system will be good for all Australians but especially for our farmers and regional communities, who were ignored by the La-bor Party for years. In politics there are always two sides. What is the Labor alternative? Labor hate the GST so much that they are going to keep it. They are trying to get away with scaring the public about individ-ual aspects of the tax package whilst promising to keep the GST. We have seen it in relation to caravan parks over the weekend. Labor say that it is terrible, but what are they going to do about it? They say that they will look at it as a matter of priority. But we thought books were Labor's highest priority—or was it tampons, or education, or beer, or clothing or the car industry? Labor's problem is that, after the l-a-w law tax cuts that disappeared, nobody believes Labor on tax. There is all of this, with no guarantees that Labor will keep the income tax cuts delivered by the Howard government. It is time for Labor to get serious about tax reform—either to put up or to shut up.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Just what is the difference be-tween GSTable sushi and GST-free sashimi?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Madam President, isn't it wonderful that we get these sorts of questions from the Labor Party? The fact of the matter is that, under our policy, the cost of many basic foods will fall. I am pointing out a very important fact which I do not think Senator Crowley is fully aware of: the fact of the matter is that, under our policy, the cost of many basic foods will fall.
—It's Democrat policy that you condemned.
—Senator Sherry, I have drawn attention earlier to the standing orders.

—The Labor Party, it should be noted, voted against this particular amendment. We have issued to the public a very useful booklet which contains a discussion on the GST food guide, and I would urge people and Senator Crowley to obtain a copy of that if they want to. If Senator Crowley wants to get into the specifics of this, there is also a food index. In relation to your specific question, Senator Crowley, I will take myself to a Japanese restaurant and I will be able to provide you with further information.

—I find it some comment on the GST that the minister says he will take himself to a Japanese restaurant to find out the answer. If that is his way of dealing with the GST, good luck to him. I do have a supplementary question.
—I suppose all the battlers are eating sashimi.

—Senator Hill suggests that this may not be the food for the battlers, but the supplementary question goes to the price of rice, which I do believe is fairly much a staple in most homes. My supplementary is: given that rice on its own is GST free, why is it GSTable when it is wrapped up in fish as sushi?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Madam President—
—Order! The level of noise in the chamber is absolutely unacceptable and there are many senators behaving in breach of the standing orders.
—The answer is that take-away food is subject to GST. Basic food which one can buy at a supermarket, like rice, is not subject to GST.

—My question is directed to Senator Kemp and it relates to the NATSEM study which shows that in Australia the rich are getting richer, the poor are getting poorer and the gap is extending. Would the minister agree that this is a tragic social problem requiring urgent action by all of us, particularly the government? What action is the government proposing to redress that serious social problem-lem?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —One of the reasons for the gap between the rich and poor in this country is the comparatively high level of unemployment which we inherited when we came into government. A lot of the government's attention quite rightly is devoted to ensuring that we can bring down that level of unemployment and create sustainable jobs. I think our record, Senator Harradine, has been particularly good in this respect. When you think that the level of unemployment under Labor rose as high as 11 per cent and now it is, as I mentioned in my earlier response, 6.7 per cent, that shows that it is just one of the major factors that this government is focusing on to address the gap between rich and poor in this country.

answer.para: Another area which I would suggest Senator Harradine look very closely at is the issue of tax reform. We believe that tax reform will make a major contribution to establishing an equitable tax system in this country. One of the things that you have been particularly concerned about, Senator Harradine, as we have, is the sort of assistance which is being provided to families. Of course under our tax system there is major assistance for families; this major tax package which will be of great benefit to families. Another area which I think is important is the huge effort which is being made to improve access to jobs by young people. In this area, we would point to the increased flexibility that the government's reforms have brought in in industrial relations. Look at the sorts of policies that are being pursued in the education area to encourage people to obtain the skills so that they can find jobs.

Senator Harradine, if we want to address issues of poverty in this country, one of the biggest things we can do is provide jobs. That was a key thing which the former Labor government failed to provide. This government, with its policies across a wide range of areas, is doing a great deal to redress the inequities which Labor left this country.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Going to the question of reducing unemployment, why is the gap getting wider as unemployment is dropping? In respect of workplace relations, why is the gap getting wider when membership of trade unions is dropping? Through you, Madam President, could the minister advise the Senate whether or not the government is treating this with such importance that it will prepare a paper for presentation to the parliament?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Let me assure Senator Harradine that the government regards issues of employment and issues of poverty as ones of great importance. In fact, as I indicated to you in my earlier response, Senator Harradine, we are addressing these issues across a wide range of areas, and I believe that this government is showing results on this score. It is absolutely unarguable that the—

—Well, when you reduce unemployment from the 11 per cent peak under the Labor Party to the 6.7 per cent of today, you are doing a great deal to help the people who are the most deprived in this community.
—Order! Senators should stop shouting.

—When you are bringing in a tax reform system which will direct very large benefits to families, which will provide for real rises in pensions and benefits, the fact of the matter is that this government has a very proud record in this area. We do not deny, Senator Harradine, that there is more work to be done. That is why this government seeks to pursue its major reform program. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Can the minister explain why breakfast bars are GST free when muesli bars are GSTable? What is the difference between a breakfast bar and a muesli bar for GST purposes?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —In the book that I referred to earlier, we have set out those aspects of food which are subject to GST and those which are GST free. There is a comprehensive index there. If the senator wishes to find out more about it, I refer her to this particular book.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Unfortunately the booklet does not provide answers to these questions, which is why we have question time, Minister. As a supplementary question, can the minister also explain why muesli sold in a cereal box is GST free yet when sold as a muesli bar it is GSTable?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —In the context of fulfilling our commitment to provide basic food GST free, the fact of the matter is that a boundary line has to be drawn. We believe that the boundary line we have drawn is fair and equitable; it was discussed with the grocery council. There will always be arguments between what should be in and what should be out. But we believe that, as a result of consultation, we have drawn a fair boundary line.

—My question is addressed to Senator Alston as the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. I refer to last week's decision by cabinet to renege on a commitment made last year by the government to the Senate to amend the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act to require all proposed releases of genetically modified organisms to be referred to the environment minister. Is the minister aware that, in a recent survey, 55 per cent of Australian farmers expressed strong concern at the potential consequences of the release of these organisms? Is he also aware of a recent AC Neilsen poll that found that 68 per cent of Australians would avoid genetically modified foods, if given the choice? Minister, was the cabinet aware when it made its decision that it would be breaking this commitment that it made to the Australian people, including the farming community? If so, how can the minister justify such a flagrant, arrogant and obvious breach of such a clear-cut and straightforward promise?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —There is no doubt that the government is always interested in the views of farmers and any other community groups, but I do not think it is a sufficient basis for sensible policy making to simply refer to expressed concerns in terms of issues. The fact is that these matters will be properly considered by the environment minister, who will have the necessary opportunity to ensure that his views are heard. As the government has already made plain, it is important that proper procedures are followed, that there is integrity in the system, that it does not simply become a political football and that decisions are not made for other than proper reasons. There will be an opportunity for the environment minister's views to be taken into account at the appropriate stage.

answer.para: That, I think, is what Senator Bartlett should be concerned about, rather than simply trying to run off the back of scare campaigns that are usually run by the Labor Party and which somehow can be identified as showing up a level of public concern in research. That is not the proper basis for decision making. The approach that we have taken is a much more responsible one.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given this display of bad faith by the government in reversing its own commitment it made to the Australian community, how is the public expected to believe anything the government says? Can the minister explain why cabinet decided to put the wishes and convenience of large agribusiness interests ahead of the community's concern about environmental protection and ahead of the government's own commitment to the Senate and the Australian people?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I trust that Senator Bartlett's approach to this issue does not reflect that of the Australian Democrats because it is not only crude populism; it is also playing to the usual conspiracy theories. I suppose that you were out there in the 1970s, bagging multinationals as hard as you could go, trying to ensure that somehow you could dig up a demon or two to run a policy off. It probably got you preselection for your efforts, but that is no substitute for sensible policy making and sensible governmental approaches and processes. We are not in the business of pandering to particular interest groups. This is not about putting the interests of agribusinesses or anyone else ahead of those that you might, on this particular day, want to advocate the cause for. It is all about putting a system in place that will stand up to proper scrutiny and that will not simply pander to the sort of populism and scare campaigns that you would like to run. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Can the minister explain why a nacho kit containing corn chips is GSTable whilst taco shells and kits are GST free? Just what is the difference between a corn chip and a taco shell for GST purposes?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I am intrigued that the Labor Party is pursuing this track because the obvious question that one might ask is: what is the Labor Party's policy in this area? What does the Labor Party propose to do in relation to food? This is going to be one of the big issues as we go towards the next election—whether there will be a roll-back in food. As I have pointed out, the government has worked closely with a wide range of bodies to look at the boundary lines between basic food and food which is taxable. We have consulted extensively with the Australian Food and Grocery Council. There will always be an argument over boundary lines but we believe that what we have done is fair and it is based, as I said, on extensive consultation.
—Madam Presi-dent, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you also explain why raw nuts are GST free while salted nuts are GSTable? Why does the addition of salt make nuts GSTable?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I think the best thing I can do for the senator is, first of all, send him a copy of the book and, secondly, point out that in these issues there is always a question of boundary lines. We believe the ones we have drawn are fair and appropriate based on wider consultation. But the big issue is: what do the Labor Party propose to do in this area? The answer is: they have not got a clue.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Senator Herron. Will the minister inform the Senate of the latest private health insurance figures and the success of the government's private health insurance reforms?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Knowles for the question because it is a good question and, once again, it is good news—bad news for the Labor Party, but good news for the Australian public. During May more than 176,000 people took out private health insurance. That is the largest ever surge in private health insurance membership and represents a massive vote of confidence in the government's reforms of an industry that was left to decay by the Labor Party. You will recall, Madam President, the percentage of fallout from private health insurance intentionally engineered by the Labor Party when they were in office over a 13-year period. This increase last month is the largest monthly increase in membership levels since the introduction of the government's 30 per cent rebate scheme—the largest monthly increase. This has never happened since private health participation figures were first published in quarterly form in 1989. The largest increase continues to be in the 30 to 34 age group. That was the group that was particularly dropping out and needed to come into the pool arrangement so that they could subsidise people like Senator Crowley as she retires from the chamber. Senator Crowley's situation is probably not rare. Perhaps Senator Schacht could say to Senator Gibbs—although I do not know who the Caesar was in Queensland—`Et tu, Brenda?'

answer.para: In answering the question about health care, the largest increase, as I mentioned, is in the 30- to 34-year-old age group, and the best news is that there are now 6.4 million Australians privately insured, or 33.5 per cent of the population. Quite simply, this is a fantastic result. I would encourage anyone who is considering joining a private health fund to do so in order to qualify for the rebate by 30 June. We have turned the tide for two reasons: the introduction of the 30 per cent rebate and the imminent introduction of Lifetime Health Cover. The coalition are about giving Australians choice in their health care needs and we have delivered on choice. The Labor Party cannot say the same. The Labor Party have opposed every initiative we have introduced to improve choice for all Australians. They had no interest in private health care, even though a significant proportion of the people they pretend to represent have got private health insurance. Importantly, our commitment to improving choice is underpinned by our commitment to Medicare and the public health system. As I said the other day, this government is the best friend Medicare has ever had. This government spends almost $1 billion a year more on Medicare than Labor did.

talk.start.para: —Senator Faulkner did not hear that because he was interjecting across the chamber. This government has spent almost $1 billion a year more on Medicare than Labor did. We have expanded access to Medicare and we have introduced new services which are now provided under Medicare. We have also increased funding to our public hospitals by 25 per cent. That bears repeating too: we have increased funding to the public hospital system by 25 per cent. Only the Labor Party could argue that this represents some sort of threat to Medicare and our public hospital system. It should also be added that the whole of the GST is going to the states so that they can provide upgraded hospital system care. The simple fact is that the biggest threat to our health care system is Labor and their ideologically driven hatred of private health care. We are all about choice, giving people the choice of two very strong and complimentary systems; Labor are about taking it away. They have not announced their policy. We are totally unaware of what Labor Party policy is in relation to health. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the Labor Party was the party that ran down private health insurance participation over so long, could the minister please advise the Senate as to what the broader ramifications have been of the increases in private health insurance participation to the wider community who now have access—
—What's the question?
—If you listened to the question, I am asking it.
—You haven't asked it.
—For heaven's sake. You are as bright as a blown globe—that is your problem. Madam President, I am keen to know what—
—What's the question?
—That is the longest preamble we have heard for weeks.
—Order! Senators on my left! The senator has asked a question and is concluding it.

—The final part of my question to the minister is: what is the benefit to the broader community of broadening the access to hospitals for people who the Labor Party had locked out after 13 years of government?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —If I may editorialise, that was a great supplementary question. The one problem with the Labor Party is that they are locked in ideology. They do not understand the dynamic of change that has occurred in the public hospital systems in Australia. For the 13 years they were in government they were unaware that a lot of technology driven changes had occurred within the health system—laparoscopic cholecystectomy, CAT scans, MRI scans, everything of that nature. They knew how to run on the politics—
—They shout out `MRI'—
—Order! There is far too much shouting.
—Are you going to take Wellington?

—Senator Faulkner! I am drawing to the attention of senators the breaches of standing orders that are going on at the present time. Some senators are interjecting persistently and I think some wilfully.
—MRI was a classic example because the teaching hospital had 16 MRIs for the whole of Australia.
—Scandal!
—Senator Carr, I have just drawn attention to the behaviour of the Senate.
—Now we have 80, and we are still paying for them.
—Senator Evans, stop shouting.

—What did we do? We expanded it into the private sector so that people could have access to it. That is what they did not understand in the whole of this—that it is a dynamic; it is constantly changing. We need to get the two sectors into equilibrium—a dynamic private hospital system and a dynamic public hospital system. That is the answer to the honourable senator's question. (Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Senator Evans asked me a question on 8 June, and I undertook to get an answer from the Minister for Aged Care. She has provided me with the following answer, which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.

quote.para: SENATOR EVANS - My question is directed to Senator Herron in his capacity representing the Minister for Aged Care. Can the minister confirm that 78 of the former employees of the Riverside Nursing Home were owed $320,000 when the facility was closed by the government on 6 March this year? Can he explain why the Minister for Aged Care has not even bothered to respond to three requests from the ANF calling on the Commonwealth to take some responsibility for those employees' entitlements? Now that media attention has shifted from Riverside, is the government hoping that the 78 employees will simply go away? Don't the former staff of Riverside deserve much better, particularly since some of them were responsible for reporting the poor care and the kerosene bath incident to the appropriate authorities? What signal does this shabby treatment of these workers send to other health workers about reporting poor care in our nursing homes? When will the government provide some justice to those former employees?

SENATOR EVANS - Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the minister saying he will get me an answer. I would appreciate it if he could do that as soon as possible, but he did not address the question as to why some action has not occurred and why the minister has not even bothered to respond to three letters from the Nurses Federation asking for assistance with this matter. I would appreciate it if he could find out what has occurred and whether or not the government is going to do anything to help these former employees who lost a total of $320,000 worth of entitlements when the government closed Riverside Nursing Home.
SENATOR HERRON - The Minister for Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question in accordance with information supplied to her:
A reply was sent to the Australian Nursing Federation (ANF) on 13 June 2000.

As outlined in the Minister's response to the ANF, employee entitlements are covered under corporations law and are the responsibility of providers. Under the Government's Employee Entitlement Safety Net Scheme, while an employer remains liable for the payment of their employee's full entitlements, taxpayer funded safety net payments are able to be made from the scheme up front to eligible employees, with the scheme then claiming those monies back from the employer if and when they become available.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Black Economy

talker.name: Cook, Sen Peter
Senator COOK
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) to a question without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to taxation.

speech.para: Mr Peter Reith is of course in the news again today. Is he in the news this time because he is beating up on working people? No. Is he in the news this time because he is intervening in a wage case to cut wages for ordinary Australians? No. Is he in the news because he is giving a handout to a textile company that has John Howard's brother, Stan Howard, as the managing director? No, he is not in the news for that. Is Mr Reith in the news today because he has put guard dogs and balaclavas on the Australian waterfront, or because he has been censured by the UN's ILO for contravention of international conventions? No, that is not the reason he is in the news today. Is Mr Reith in the news today because he—Penthouse Peter Reith—has bought a cheap, for him, penthouse in the Domain Apartments, the tower of power in Melbourne, from Liberal Party Treasurer Ron Walker's construction company, Hudson Conway? No, he is not in the news for that. Nor is he in the news for the fact that that apartment can be let GST free while Mr Reith supports the imposition of GST on Australian battlers in caravan parks. No, he is not in the news for that.

The reason why the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is in the news today is that the Prime Minister has told us, yet again, that Mr Reith is wrong, that Mr Reith has just misunderstood or does not know. Let me go to the actual transcript of the interview with the Prime Minister. The reporter said:

quote.para: Well, Peter Reith on another issue today said that cracking down on the black economy would reap $7 billion estimated windfall for the States, and the Shadow Treasurer Simon Crean said that proves the government's going to collect more tax than it ever said.

speech.para: The Prime Minister, John Howard—and this is a classic answer—said:

quote.para: Well, that was Peter's personal calculation. It's not based on any Treasury estimate. And the Treasury advice is what is in the budget. And we have no evidence before us from Treasury or any other official source to say that the increase collection will be greater. So there's no official or indeed semi-official figure of $7 billion.

talk.start.para: —That is a comprehensive put-down.
—Yes, it is a comprehensive put-down. The Prime Minister went on to say:

quote.para: Mr Reith was expressing a view that he thought the new system would be good in cracking down on tax cheats ...

speech.para: Here is a minister comprehensively de-molished by the Prime Minister. This is a minister—Mr Reith—who has an image problem in the Australian electorate. Many people in Australia do not believe that this minister tells the truth. Many people in Australia regard him as loose with the facts. Many people in Australia believe that, in his case, he would never let the facts stand in the way of a good story.

The Prime Minister nailed him today; the Prime Minister joined the majority. The Prime Minister expressed a view that what Mr Reith was telling the Australian punters was not true either. There is a possibility that maybe in all these circumstances we have it wrong. There is the possibility that yesterday Mr Reith might have been—for the first time in a long time, if ever—actually telling the truth, and that there is in fact a bigger windfall than the government is disclosing. There is possibly truth in the front page we saw in the Weekend Australian not last Saturday but the Saturday before, which said that the government is building up a massive war chest by overtaxing Australians, and that it is not coming clean about how much tax it will raise because in the 2001 federal election it wants to pork-barrel its way to victory, buy votes, placate the National Party and do a number of other things. That is a possibility.

When I balance the two possibilities—is Mr Reith telling the truth and it is the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Treasury officials who have misled us; or are the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Treasury officials telling the truth and is Mr Reith expressing his personal opinion?—I must say that, on the balance of probability, no court in the land would come down on Mr Reith's side. Every court I know of where credibility counts in a witness would be on the other side of the fence, and that is not because they think the Prime Minister is any great shakes in the truth stakes either. They know about the `never ever' promise; they know that Mr Costello does not go to the country anymore because he is regarded as the man who has taken away jobs from the bush. They all know that, but it is a terrible slight that their credibility is greater than Mr Reith's. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Yet again we have heard from the Labor Party in the taking note of answers debate which we have had for weeks and weeks now on issues related to the implementation of the new tax system. Of course, we have had scaremonger after scaremonger on the part of the opposition in this chamber as the weeks have gone by. Today, they have resorted to personal attack and have launched a personal attack on the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business in regard to his comments on the impact of the new tax system on the black economy. What has Senator Cook just said? He has said that Mr Reith was put down by the Prime Minister. What the Prime Minister said was that no detailed calculations had been done in relation to the revenue that might be derived from the black economy as a result of the tax changes, following on the registrations that have been achieved for the Australian business number.

speech.para: The fact with regard to those registrations is that, as I understand it, it was expected that some 2.3 million businesses would be registered for an Australian business number under the new tax system and registered for GST and that, at present, some 2.7 million businesses have registered. So, on the one hand, it is accurate for the Prime Minister to say that no detailed calculations have been done with regard to the revenue implications of that; but it is also reasonable for Peter Reith to say that, given that the registrations are higher than expected, Senator Cook, there will be more revenue generated as a result of that.

talk.start.para: —That is not what he said. Read the Hansard.

—Of course, this revenue is being generated, Senator Cook, from the black economy, because those extra 400,000 businesses that are registered are businesses that were unknown prior to this new tax system being introduced. They are businesses that were, clearly, operating in the black economy and not paying their fair share of tax. As a consequence of them not paying their fair share of tax, many other people in Australia were paying more than their fair share of tax. I remember, Senator Cook, that in the various committee hearings we had with regard to the introduction of the new tax system, you argued quite strenu-ously that the new tax system would have absolutely no effect on the black economy and that the black economy would continue unabated. Yet, here today in your debate, you claim that the government is hiding something and that in fact we are going to raise more revenue from the new tax system because of its impact on the black economy. You have directly contradicted the view that you put when we were working on the committee hearings last year in relation to the new tax system.

speech.para: Senator Cook has directly contradicted himself in that regard. Of course, there is absolutely no doubt that the new tax system will make an impact with regard to raising revenue from the black economy, because it is shifting the tax structure to an indirect tax system. It is ensuring that those who avoid their fair share of income tax because of tax avoidance mechanisms will pay at least some of that tax when they purchase goods and services, because they will be paying the GST to which they were not previously subject.

talk.start.para: —It doesn't work in the other OECD countries.

—Senator Cook should be well aware of that. There is absolutely no doubt that that will have an impact on bringing those businesses previously operating in the black economy out into the open as taxpayers—not only because they will now be paying tax on goods and serv-ices they purchase, even if they might continue to avoid some income tax through various schemes, but because the fact that the goods and services tax operates as a value added tax means that, if they are operating bus-inesses and they want to get their refunds at each point of production, they have to reg-is-ter to achieve that. That is exactly what has happened, I would remind Senator Cook. That is exactly what has happened: these bus-inesses have registered because they need to be able to reclaim their business input taxes at each stage of production, and so we now have some 2.7 million businesses apply-ing for registration under the goods and ser-vices tax structure, as against the 2.3 million bus-inesses that were expected and predicted to do so by the tax office. That obviously will ensure that there is a fairer tax system and that there will be a capacity for the government to return tax to the community, either in the form of additional programs to their benefit or in the form of future tax cuts if it eventuates that, as a consequence of that, more revenue is raised. As the Prime Minister has said, no analysis of that has yet been done, and so we do not know the effect of that yet. (Time expired)

—This morning on AM the Prime Minister made great claims about his honesty and integrity. Of course, these are very lofty ideals which, if true, one should expect from gov-ernment. However, it is quite clear that these lofty ideals are not shared by Mr Reith. Yester-day Mr Reith made claims about the black economy that there were double the Treasury estimates in terms of returns to the Com-monwealth. When questioned about the sources for these claims, Mr Reith muttered something about collecting various evidence from his travels through the world of bus-iness. It was the Prime Minister who in-dicated this morning that there was no official support for those claims—no statis-tics, no evidence for that proposition. In fact, when we examine the claims, we notice that in particular it is now apparent that Mr Reith simply made it up. He is well practised at fabrication. We have seen this over recent times. With regard to the Dubai fiasco, he made claims about his involvement in that matter that he had nothing to do with the thugs in balaclavas or the guard dogs and that the waterfront reform initiative that he pro-posed was, of course, a completely innocent exercise. The conspiracy pro-ceedings before the Federal Court demon-strated that to be completely untrue.

speech.para: We saw in other examples that this minister has made claims before the parliament that simply do not bear scrutiny when it comes to the detailed examination of what he is actually saying. We have seen the repudiation of this minister now by the Prime Minister and by the Treasurer, where he simply stated in the press this morning that Mr Reith was mistaken. We noticed on commercial radio today claims that in fact Mr Reith is a liar, according to the statements by the spokes-person for the Treasurer. A woman spokes-person for the Treasurer is cited as saying that, this morning.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The senator is not quoting what he purported to have read in the paper, and to refer to the minister as a liar is completely out of order. He should be asked to retract it and apologise.
—Senator Carr, it is unparliamentary to use those words whether they are true or not, so I would ask you to withdraw, please.

—I withdraw. I notice the claims are made by others in the press in recent times. It seems that Mr Reith comes from a particular brand of Liberal Party apparatchiks in Victoria. A Brighton Grammar clique is operating. We have seen a whole series of them come forward—the `Hooray Harrys' out of Melbourne. We have seen Alan Stockdale. We have seen `Punchy' John Rossiter. A whole series of them have moved through the ranks of the Liberal Party and sought to establish themselves as the saviours of the country. Mr Reith now sees himself particularly as the saviour of this government. He has this strange notion that if something is not cooking too well you turn up the heat. That is essentially what he is seeking to do by his various outlandish statements, his extraordinary claims and the head-kicking techniques that he has sought to develop. What we have noticed again and again is that Mr Reith is simply out of control. This government has a real problem on its hands. One gaffe after another has been made by this minister who seeks to establish himself as the saviour of the government. He clearly has a huge credibility problem, and no matter what sort of puff pieces are presented by various journalists in this country there will not be any movement away from that basic problem.

speech.para: Mr Reith's role in the waterfront dispute became a national and even an international scandal, and it is well known that his actions were not able to bear the scrutiny of the Federal Court of this country. What is not so well known is his activity in a number of other affairs; for instance, the minister's role, and his constant denial of his role, in the case of the lockout of meatworkers at O'Connor's at Packenham. He sought to encourage and develop support for the owners of that particular enterprise who have slashed the wages and conditions of workers by up to $200 a week. We have seen a proposition imposed upon the workers at that site where there is no job security and where they have been stood down without pay. They can in fact be paid for as little as five hours a week. This minister has claimed over and over again that he has no knowledge of the development in that particular case; yet there are 750 files kept by his department relating to this dispute. We know that he is deeply involved in this particular matter; yet he claims that he has no knowledge of it. A pattern is being established where the minister is quite prepared to say one thing, when it can be demonstrated that he is doing another. This is a minister who is quite happy to go through his political life and for it to be known that he has no credibility. But increasingly he seems to be able to present himself as the saviour of the government by seeking to be the head kicker and making outlandish statements. He is quite clearly losing control of himself and his political credibility as a consequence. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I also rise to take note of the question with respect to Mr Reith. I make the opening comment that the real purpose of trying to bring discredit upon Mr Reith—which has failed so far—is that Mr Reith took on the Maritime Union of Australia and won. Why wouldn't you do that when you had a bottleneck there creating problems for the Australian public? Also, the question has to be asked: why, when only 20 per cent of people in the work force today are unionised, do 60 per cent of the people on the other side come from the Australian union movement? I think that is where the scandal is. The scandal is not in a minister being open, transparent, forthright and honest with the Australian people prior to the introduction of the new tax system on 1 July. We know that it is going to work. We know that the propaganda is waning at the moment. Do you know why it is waning? It is waning because even the media, the people that do the doorstops, know that they are going to get tax reimbursements. They are going to get tax back. They are going to get a pay rise of between $50 and perhaps $100 a fortnight in their pay packages. That is why they are not supporting the Labor Party's position of knocking the GST and the new tax system in itself.

speech.para: There is another avenue of support for the coalition government's GST—the Howard-Beazley-Lees GST—and it is coming from the closest counterpart that the Australian Labor Party has in the Southern Hemisphere; it is coming from our cousins in New Zealand. The Prime Minister, Helen Clark, said she likes it. She is never going to take it back. It is working. She is quite happy with it. And why wouldn't she be happy with it? She is getting more revenue in than she anticipated. She inherited it, of course, from the National Party, which is somewhat like a counterpart of the coalition party of Australia that is currently in power here. Not only that: the revered intellectual David Lange, former—I might say successful—Prime Minister of New Zealand also said, `It works.' Two Labour Party prime ministers from New Zealand said it works. No-one could argue rationally New Zealand is not a microcosm of Australia over there. Both said it works. They are not going to roll it back. Do you know what, Madam Deputy President? I would vouch for the fact that if Mr Beazley—God forbid—ever got onto the treasury bench he would not roll it back. He knows that if he rolls it back he will have to raise income taxes, company taxes and excises. He will have to put everything back into place that is so bad, so debilitating, for Australia—everything that is so negative with respect to our exports that we would be the poor white trash of Asia again, as Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew once referred to Australia.

We know through our research, particularly using New Zealand, that the black economy will bring in far more than the anticipated $3 billion. Why wouldn't Mr Reith, being honest, open and forthright with the Australian public, when he was reasonably sure, when he said it was his personal opinion, say the $3 billion would extend to $7 billion? Of course it will. We know by the rate of the Australian business numbers that are being issued that the black economy out there is something that had to be controlled, and they are going to get caught.

We also know that tax cuts are not going to amount to just $12 billion. I anticipate, on the information that I have been given, that the tax cuts are going to be closer to $15 billion, and that is going to create something of a spending boom in Australia. We never, ever taxed tourists here with respect to a GST. The $17 billion tourism industry is also going to attract a $1.7 billion GST if the same amount applies across the board there too, and I anticipate that it will. All of these aggregations add up to good news for Australia. It is a great new tax. It is great for exports. Roll on 1 July: we are going to go gang busters. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I was going to say that in describing Mr Reith as open, forthright, transparent and honest Senator Lightfoot was deliberately misleading, but of course that would be unparliamentary, so I will not do that. But the fact of the matter is that no-one could accept that as a description of this minister. In fact, the answer from Senator Kemp to the question that was asked of him today was essentially that the comments that Mr Reith made were all his own work. He said:

quote.para: We are talking about a lot of black economy here. Treasury's estimates have been an extra $3.5 billion from the black economy.

speech.para: Mr Costello's spokeswoman was straight off the blocks to completely repudiate that. If you look at the Hansard transcripts of the estimates they show that Treasury has not made any estimates which show any such additional money coming from the black economy. These comments—not what he estimates might be growth on top of the Treasury estimates but in fact the basic comments that he made—have been utterly repudiated by Mr Costello's spokeswoman. They are utterly repudiated if you look at the Hansard. They are utterly repudiated if you look at the Prime Minister's comments. These comments were all Mr Reith's own work and, frankly, quite misleading. But let us face facts: Mr Reith is not very good at doing numbers. He has totally shot his campaign for leadership of the Liberal Party. He has blown it away out of his own mouth. But he has never been very good at making promises to the Australian people that he can keep.

talk.start.para: —Didn't do the Maritime Union of Australia—

—I am very glad that Senator Lightfoot has raised the issue of the waterfront, because here is one of the prime examples of where Mr Reith misled the Australian people. He disrupted the waterfront, caused a lot of anguish, grief and pain across Australia, disrupted businesses, spent millions of dollars and then got caught out. But what did he say? When he finally got a deal from the waterfront he said, `I have got these promises in writing from the steve-dores about what they are going to achieve, and they are going to achieve it very quickly.' Of course he never had one thing in writing, and they were quick to repudiate that comment when they got a chance to on the Hansard.

speech.para: But what did Mr Reith say back in April of 1998? He said that by April of the next year he was going to have a national five- port average of 25 crane movements per hour. That is what he was going to achieve. All of this was going to be fixed he said. And, of course, that is not the case. In fact, in the last quarter the productivity rate—after spending all of this money and causing all of this anguish—went down. It went down from 19.6 to 19. And one of the key issues, particularly in the fall in the performance on the docks, was a shortage of labour and equipment breakdowns at P&O in Melbourne and industrial problems at Patrick in Sydney. Far from the problem being solved, it is going backwards.

But another one of Mr Reith's indica-tors—and these were all going to be fixed by April of 1999; `It is all going to be hunky-dory. We have spent all this money. It is all going to be fixed,' Mr Reith told us—was that we were going to have 97 per cent of ship calls finding a berth available within four hours of the scheduled time. What happened? In the last quarter it went down from 93 per cent to 88 per cent—far from going up, it is going down. Mr Reith is telling us we are going to solve these problems, and the actuality is that the indicators are going in the reverse direction. So the berth availability indicator was wrong; it has gone down. The average waiting time for ships—and Senator Lightfoot, I am sure, will be keen to know this—unable to obtain a berth in December was 21 hours. This is the great achievement of Mr Reith.

talk.start.para: —Because the economy is booming.
—Senator Lightfoot, you have had your time.

—This is a great achievement. Mr Reith is seeing all of the indicators on the waterfront go backwards. I am glad you introduced this issue, Senator Lightfoot, in this debate about Mr Reith, because it clearly demonstrates the point: it is easy to say things, it is easy to tell the Australian people what you think they want to hear, but the reality in this case is that Mr Reith on the issue of the tax cheats has been proven wrong. (Time expired)

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha
Senator STOTT DESPOJA
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked by Senators Stott Despoja and Bartlett today, relating to genetically-modified organisms.

speech.para: The concerns that the Democrats raised in question time today related to the fact that the new amendments—the amendments being proposed by the government to the Gene Technology Bill 2000—will no longer have a requirement for advice from the Minister for the Environment and Heritage or any advice regarding the release of GMOs if it is vol-unteered in relation to, say, potential adverse effect of the release of genetically modified organisms to be incorporated. The Demo-crats are concerned for two reasons: not only that the government has blatantly and arrogantly reneged on an agreement, on a deal, between the Australian Democrats and the government on this pressing environmental and health issue but also, obviously, that there is not equal weighting being given to the issue of the health impacts and the environmental impacts of the release of GMOs into our community.

I draw the Senate's attention to the remarks by Senator Herron today. He seemed to think that health and safety concerns and environmental concerns were going to be given equal consideration. He emphasised the government's so-called strong concern for including environmental protections but the same time of course had to acknowledge that the role of the environment minister has been completely undermined under this new proposal—not the original amendments, not the original proposal that the Democrats and the government agreed to, but these new proposals coming from the government over this weekend.

I note for the record that Senator Hill outlined his own commitment to the issue of genetically modified organisms in regard to their environmental impact and the environment minister having a role in the approval of GMOs. This is in the Senate Hansard. He said on 26 June last year:

quote.para: There are new areas that people are recognising in which the Commonwealth has a particular responsibility. Genetically modified organisms is one such area and, as honourable senators will know, the government is setting up the Office of the Gene Technology Regulator within the Department of Health to provide approvals. What I can say to the Senate tonight is that matters that affect the environment will be referred to the environment minister for assessment and advice by that independent regulator. That will ultimately be provided for through an amendment to this legislation when it passes in conjunction with the law that is going to be put in place to set up the new GTR.

speech.para: That is a quote from Senator Robert Hill confirming, believing, that the environment minister would have a decisive role in whether or not GMOs were released and whether or not they would be responsible for assessing their potential impact on the environment. Of course, he has been rolled in cabinet; we all know that. It is particularly unfortunate. But it does go to the heart of the matter, and that is this government's blatant disregard for consumer and community concerns in relation to the issue of GMOs.

We see this emphasised in the last couple of weeks yet again by the Prime Minister, who last year—in December I believe, at the eleventh hour—stepped in and interfered with the state and territory health ministers' deliberations concerning a national mandatory labelling scheme for GMOs in relation to food. Now the Prime Minister has put to the states and territories, in an extraordinary fashion, that not only did he see fit to postpone the introduction of those labelling laws, but that he has sought to water them down. Understandably, that has been met with outrage, not only from the relevant state and territory ministers, but from the community.

Again it goes to the very heart of the matter, and that is that this government just is not in touch with what the community is thinking. This is not about setting back the agenda in relation to scientific or biotechnology discovery or research. It is not about clamping down on GMOs that might have future benefit for the community, whether it is in a health, environmental or food sense. It is about good public practice, ensuring that the community is not scared off.

We know—and certainly it was quoted in question time today by the Democrats—that at least 90 per cent of consumers, if given the choice, would reject GM products. That partly arises from the community's lack of awareness or understanding of what is available at the moment. They, like most Australians, recognise that these products crept in by stealth in the mid-1990s due to a lack of regulation. The government's response to that minimal regulation now is to come up with the gene technology bill, which we should have been debating in the parliament roughly about this time. There are problems with that bill, however, as we have seen from the draft legislation and from the public consultation processes, including issues of liability, commercial-in-confidence and, of course, the role of the environment minister. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The Committee notes that the circumstances of the accidental death of the cadet may not have been covered by the Act and that your Declaration has prevented such an outcome occurring again. Dear Senator Coonan

Thank you for your letter dated 13 April 2000 relating to the concerns of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances regarding the Declaration of Persons Taken to be Employed by the Commonwealth under subsection 9(5) of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 (the OHS(CE) Act).

The limitations of the application of the OHS(CE) Act to which I referred in my letter of 6 April 2000 relates to the definition of “employees” (section 9) who are covered by the Act. Similar limitations apply to coverage under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (the SRC Act) which provides workers' compensation for Commonwealth employees. Under both Acts, the Minister has the authority to issue a declaration of the type referred to above to overcome such limitations in respect of coverage where deemed appropriate by the Minister. Members of the Australian Services Cadet Scheme (ASCS) do not fall within the definition of employees under both Acts. A declaration providing continued workers' compensation coverage for ASCS members was made when the SRC Act was introduced in 1988, but no such declaration under the OHS(CE) Act was made by the relevant Minister in 1991 when that Act was enacted.

You also asked whether the cadet killed in the accident, or her family, were seriously disadvantaged by a lack of coverage. The short answer is no. I am advised that the Australian Government Solicitor recently confirmed that the cadet was covered as a third party by the operation of section 17 of the OHS(CE) Act. Acting on this advice, Comcare has now carried out an investigation which has concluded that there has been a breach of the “third party” provisions of the Act. The results of that investigation have been conveyed to the Department of Defence (the employer for the purposes of the Act) which has been asked for a response detailing what action it has taken or proposes to take in relation to exercising its duty of care towards members of the ASCS. In particular, it has been asked how it will structure activities to ensure adequate supervision of cadets.

In terms of entitlement to compensation for ASCS members and their dependents, there is no financial payment available to dependents or other relatives of deceased employees under the OHS(CE) Act. However, as mentioned, members of the ASCS have coverage under the SRC Act. In the event of the death of a person covered under the SRC Act, there is provision for reimbursement of funeral expenses and, subject to dependency, there may also be an entitlement to death benefits.

For completeness, I mention that the Commonwealth and its agencies (other than Government Business Enterprises) have the Shield of the Crown under the OHS(CE) Act. This is in line with long standing Commonwealth policy.
I hope this additional information will be sufficient for the Committee to finalise its consideration of this matter.
Yours sincerely
PETER REITH
Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

Senator Helen Coonan
Chair,
Senate Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Australian Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2601
Dear Helen

I refer to your letter of 17 February 2000 (Cttee/23/2000) concerning Northern Prawn Fishery (NPF) Management Plan 1995 Direction No. NPFD 30. This direction, which was made under subsection 17(5A) of the Fisheries Management Act 1991 requires Turtle Excluder Devices (TEDs) and Bycatch Reduction Devices (BRDs) to be used in the NPF from 15 April 2000.

I have sought advice from the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) in responding to your queries about the commencement date on 15 April 2000; and whether the time of five months between the making of the Direction and its commencement is sufficient to allow the affected operators to comply.

The Northern Prawn Management Advisory Committee (NORMAC) and AFMA agreed, in 1998, to the mandatory introduction of TEDs and BRDs on all vessels in the NPF from the start of the fishing season in 2000. However, as a result of subsequent consultations and analysis of data the requirement will now commence on 15 April 2000.

In arriving at the decision to implement TEDs and BRDs, NORMAC and its Research and Environment Committee considered a number of factors affecting turtle bycatch and mortality. For example they considered fishing gear, seasonal, shot duration, target species and spatial influences. On the basis of logbook data and research programs NORMAC determined that TEDs and BRDs would apply to all vessels operating in all areas throughout the season. A particular factor which was considered was whether TEDs should be required while operators are targeting banana rather than tiger prawns.

During the first part of the season commencing on 1 April 2000, NPF operators mainly target banana prawns and evidence suggests that the average duration of each shot of prawn nets during the early part of the season is 60 minutes but that after the first half of April tends to lengthen to 90 minutes as the targeting of banana prawns diminishes and the targeting of tiger prawns begins. Evidence also suggests that turtles caught in a net have a relatively higher chance of survival when the duration of the shot is shorter.

NPF operators believe that because of the nature of the banana prawn fishery, there is a high probability of prawn loss with TEDs and further study in this area is needed. At this stage the two week exemption only applies for the 2000 fishing season. The TED/BRD sub-committee established by NORMAC has suggested a process to assess how turtle bycatch and prawn catch will be affected by TED/BRDs while targeting banana prawns, which will be considered by NORMAC on 17 March 2000.
In summary, the Direction does not require TEDs/BRDs to be used in the first two weeks of the 2000 fishing season because of:
short shot duration;
expected low rates of turtle mortality;
very little trialing of TEDs when targeting bananas; and
expected high rates of prawn loss.

There has been adequate notice of commencement. Although NPFD 30 was gazetted on 16 November 1999, the decision to introduce TEDs in the NPF dates back to 1998. Since that decision until the gazettal there has been extensive consultation with industry, workshops and trials of appropriate TEDs. The NORMAC TED/BRD sub-committee that considered research undertaken in the development of TED/BRDs and developed appropriate definitions would like to allow for the development of even more effective devices by industry. A process by which operators who wish to continue refining TED/BRDs can do so is provided through scientific permits being granted for an alternative TED or BRD. Such a scientific permit exempts the operator from NPFD 30. The sub-committee also considered an approach for more extensive testing of TED/BRDs during banana prawn targeting. This approach was considered by NORMAC on 17 March 2000. Operators have been kept informed of the work of the sub-committee and of NORMAC recommendations and AFMA decisions.
I trust that this response adequately addresses your concerns.
Yours sincerely
WARREN TRUSS

CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Coonan

Thank you for your letter of 17 February 2000 concerning increases to the fees charged for an application to approve an advertisement lodged under regulation 5F of the Therapeutic Goods Regulations (the Regulations). I apologise for the delay in responding.

The functions set out in regulation 5G of the Regulations, for the Secretary to approve applications for advertisements published in mainstream print media, have been delegated to two peak industry bodies in accordance with subregulations 5Q(2), (3), (4) and (5) of the Regulations. The two peak bodies are the Proprietary Medicines Association of Australia (PMAA), and the Complementary HealthCare Council of Australia (CHCA). The Secretary's power to approve applications under regulation 5G has not been delegated to any other person.

At the time the fees were set in 1997 for the function of pre-clearing advertisements intended for publication in mainstream print media, the amounts calculated by industry were based on fees charged by the two industry bodies under a voluntary self-regulatory system of controls, before the controls were incorporated into the Regulations.
Following the incorporation of the pre-clearance function under the statute, the cost to industry of performing statutory functions has risen considerably. Reasons for the additional costs include:

a much higher level of accountability for decisions made, now that these decisions have legal consequences under both the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 and Regulations and may be the subject of review by both the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and also the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977;

new quarterly reporting requirements imposed by the Therapeutic Goods Administration to enable the latter to monitor the exercise of the Secretary's power and functions under regulations 5G and 5L, requiring additional resources;

the increase in the number of applications for pre-clearance of advertisements published in mainstream print media, now that pre-clearance is legally required under statute whereas before December 1997 this was not a statutory requirement:

the level of complexity and sophistication of advertisements published over time, particularly in relation to increased numbers of lengthy advertorials, as some advertisers seek to find loopholes or weaknesses in the Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code. This has led to a considerable increase in the amount of time required to be spent on the pre-clearance function;

involvement in statutory committees established under the Regulations, such as the Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code Council (RR 42B and 42C), relevant to the industry's involvement in implementing the Therapeutic Goods Advertising Code through the pre-clearance function it performs; and
the need for industry to fully recover its costs in performing statutory functions under the Regulations to a high standard.

All these factors have contributed to the increase in the fees being charged by the PMAA and CHCA in fully discharging statutory responsibilities under the Regulations. The change in the structure of the fees more accurately reflects the actual costs incurred by the delegates when performing functions under R. 5G of the Regulations.
I hope this information meets with the concerns raised by the Committee.
Yours sincerely
GRANT TAMBLING
